desc.objtitle:
Sketch for Joseph Ordering Simeon to be Bound,
Object 1 (BUT158.1)

objnote.p: This is a full-size preliminary water color drawing for the finished water color in the Fitzwilliam Museum (Object 23, Butlin 156).

illustration.illusobjdesc: This sketch illustrates Genesis 42:19, 25, and anticipates Blake's more finished watercolor of the same design (Butlin 156). In the right third of the design, Joseph's brother Simeon is being bound at the wrists by another man, presumably one of Joseph's servants. Simeon kneels in a lunging position, facing the right edge of the design with his left leg forward and his right leg extended behind him with toes flexed. Both legs are bent; the right is bare from the knee down, while the left is mostly covered by a cloth that wraps around Simeon's back. He is nude from the waist up, and his torso faces forward and to the right. His arms extend downward and to the right; the left arm bends slightly. Simeon's palms face one another, and his fingers are spread as the servant clasps manacles around both wrists. Simeon twists at the shoulders and neck, turning his head to the left and looking at the brothers behind him. He has a short hair and a beard. His mouth opens slightly, and his expression suggests fear or despair. The man who binds Simeon stands to the right of him, facing forward and to the left. He has short, curly hair and a beard; he is nude from the waist up but may be covered by a skirt or other garment from waist to knees. He stands with his left foot forward, just to the right of Simeon's. He bends at the waist, lowering his left arm to secure the shackles around Simeon's wrists. His right arm bends at approximately ninety degrees, and he holds his forearm horizontally across his waist. In his right hand he holds a chain that extends down to the manacles in his left hand. The man's head turns downward and to the left; his eyes are downcast, likely to look toward Simeon. To the left of Simeon and his captor, on a raised platform, a male figure (very probably Joseph) sits sideways on a throne-like chair and leans against its back. He faces right and sits with his left knee forward, his left foot drawn back underneath him, and his right leg bent and extended back behind him in a position that mimics Simeon's. Joseph leans forward and extends his bent arms in front of him to rest his elbows on the chair back. His hands are raised and clasped together in a prayerful posture, and he may bring his forehead forward to rest on them. Joseph stares at the right edge of the design; his mouth opens slightly, and his facial expression may suggest grief. Joseph wears a long-sleeved gown. He has long, curly hair. Behind Joseph, in the left third of the design, the other nine brothers kneel or stand. Most of them look on as Simeon is bound. In the center of the kneeling group is an older-looking man with short, curly hair and a beard. He is nude from the waist up and covered from the waist down with a skirt or other draping cloth. His lower body faces toward the right as his knees rest on the ground and his flexed feet support him. He leans backward slightly as his torso twists away from the viewer, who sees him from behind. His arms are lowered on either side and embrace the brothers on his left and right; his right arm bends at ninety degrees. The man's head turns to the right to watch Simeon. On his left is a younger-looking man with short, curly hair who faces right and kneels in a similar posture. He may wear a skirt or a long, sleeveless gown. His muscular right arm extends down and forward so that his hand rests on the right hip of the older man. His fingers extend forward. The man's shoulders hunch forward as he leans against the older man with his head and eyes down. At the older man's right hand is another man(?) with long hair. He faces forward and appears to kneel with his legs spread, though only his left leg is visible from behind the older man's embrace. His arms bend upward to cross in front of his chest, and the fingers of his right hand curve downward as if touching his left shoulder. The man's head turns to face right as he gazes at Simeon with an open mouth. Behind these three embracing figures are two more who also appear to kneel. One emerges at right of the group, just behind the figure with crossed arms. Only his head and raised left arm are visible. He faces forward and to the right. The palm of his raised left hand faces the viewer, and his fingers are spread. At left and above the embracing trio is the curly hair of another figure. Standing above these figures are four more brothers. They are, from left to right: a gowned man with long hair who faces right and leans his head on the shoulder of the man in front of him; a man in nearly identical posture whose eyes close as he lowers his head and raises his hands in a prayerful posture; a man with short, curly hair and a beard who faces right and raises his head to look forward with an open mouth; and a gowned man who faces to the right, and raises his hands on the sides of his head in a gesture of grief. The scene takes place in an indoor space with the floor divided into two levels. The single step up creates a platform, which holds the chair on which one of the brothers (probably Joseph) leans. Two sets of seven vertical lines may represent pilasters or folds in floor-length curtains. The back wall of the design is shaded, but more defined shadows appear at back of the group of brothers, behind the feet and below the knees of the older kneeling man at left, underneath Simeon's left leg and foot, underneath his captor's left foot, and underneath Joseph's chair.
